notes: The 4-piston Brembo calipers from the Genesis Coupe Track/R-Spec are a popular upgrade for other Hyundai/Kia models. They are relatively cheap used. Some applications require custom brackets, but they are a massive upgrade over the floating calipers.

partName: Mitsubishi 4G63 Parts in Hyundai Beta Engines
notes: Early Hyundai 'Beta' engines share architecture with Mitsubishi. While not identical, many internal components (valve springs, some bearings) and bolt patterns for transmissions are shared or adaptable. The 1.6L/1.8L/2.0L Beta is essentially a distant cousin of the 4G63.

partName: Kia Stinger / Genesis G70 LSD Swap
notes: The Limited Slip Differential (LSD) from the Stinger GT or G70 Sport can be swapped into lower trim models (that came with open diffs) if the housing and axle flanges match. Essential for drifting or track use.

The 'World Engine' (GEMA) project means the Hyundai Theta II (Genesis Coupe 2.0T), Mitsubishi 4B11T (Evo X), and Chrysler World Engine (Caliber SRT-4) share a block design. While heads and internals differ, the bellhousing patterns and some mounting points are shared.

partName: Theta II Engine Rod Bearing Failure
notes: The 2.0T and 2.4L Theta II engines are notorious for rod bearing failure due to machining debris. Hyundai/Kia issued a massive recall (Campaign 132/162). Always check if the engine has been replaced or the knock sensor update applied before modifying. The 'N' engines are significantly reinforced but early ones still had some issues.

partName: Elantra N (VN) Turbo Upgrade for Veloster N
notes: The turbocharger from the Elantra N (and Kona N) flows more air than the early Veloster N turbo. It is a direct bolt-on upgrade for the Veloster N, capable of 350+ whp with tuning. Often called the 'EN Turbo' swap.

The 3.3T Lambda II engine is very sensitive to spark plug gap when tuned. Stock gap is too wide for increased boost. Gapping down to 0.022-0.024" is mandatory for any tune to prevent blowout. HKS M45IL plugs are the standard upgrade.

partName: Hyundai/Kia High Pressure Fuel Pump (HPFP) Upgrade
notes: The stock HPFP on the 2.0T engines can crash at high RPM/boost. Upgrading to the Sonata N-Line or a dedicated aftermarket pump is recommended for reliability above stock power levels.
